narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor define the topic of study?
comments: I came into the course without really knowing anything concrete about structural design, but I can honestly say I feel like I have a solid grasp on the fundamentals of wooden design for the stage. The course is "structured" so well, there is no excuse to not tackle the homework material each week as suggested.
It was clear what topics we were studying based on the class introduction and syllabus.

narratives.question_text: How clearly did the instructor outline the expectation for the course, classroom activity and homework?
comments: Expectations were made clear on the first day, and the application of these expectations never shifted.
Again, this was made clear from the syllabus.
It was very clearly stated in the beginning of the semester, and reminded before every tests.

narratives.question_text: How well were individual class sessions prepared and presented?
comments: Ben knew exactly how long each lecture was going to take, and when he knew a given lecture was going to be shorter, he would take that time at the top of class to discuss the rest of our experience here.

Very generalized in going though each section in the book, but leaving room to still discover on the homework. Somethings were made more difficult this way and luckily our TA was always available to fill in those gaps. But if the TA were less available I feel like I may have missed some things.
It was like clockwork. Class rarely ran long and was often due to questions and other investigations instigated by the class, only once by Ben.
The instructor was always prepared for each session, but I did not always feel that we covered concepts in a way that either related to the homework, or related to the broader field of physics.
Classes where we talked about real world applications were the most rewarding and helped to realize how what we were learning actually works.
On some days with simple topics, the class seemed to be 5 to 15 minutes too long. On more complicated topics, it was just right however.

narratives.question_text: How well did lectures fit within the boundaries of the course?
comments: Everything built excellently (no pun intended) toward the single point of beam design.
The instructor always stayed on-topic and the lecture material was particularly useful when relating to production work.
I didn't use it, but having the Structures hole as an option should never go away.
The importance of and depth of the course material warrants the amount of work.
It is a lot of work, but there is a lot to cover, and I feel much more fit to defend a structural design decision than ever before.
More work than most classes, but expected and appropriate to the course.
The workload is tough, but appropriate for the material. I also appreciate the two-week deadlines for homework.

The amount of work was reasonable. Wish if the problems in the text book were more diverse and was organized better. It would've been helpful if it was noticed when the previous homework was needed to solve for the next assignment. ie. chapter 3.3 and 3.4.
It's A LOT of hours hunched over the book. I suppose it's necessary, but it's something I'm not fond of. That's a personal problem though.... haha

narratives.question_text: How available was the instructor for help outside the classroom?
comments: Ben's a pretty busy guy. I never tried to talk to him about class, but I am sure he isn't as available as the other professors.
If there's a question just ask. EVERYONE SHOULD BE TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THIS.
Any time I had a question we'd find a time to discuss it, and when I missed a class we scheduled a make up session immediately.
Ben is a busy man, but available upon appointment. Steph was great as TA as well and always happy to answer questions.
I did not seek the instructor outside of class time. I was able to schedule help with the TA, though.

narratives.question_text: How useful were assignments in furthering an understanding of the topic?
comments: At times, I felt like I learned more doing the homework than I did in class.
Anything the homework questions didn't cover we were able to ask about in the review sessions before the exams.
Practice makes perfect with math.
Not just useful but essential
The homework was very helpful in preparing for exams.
The homework is exactly what we needed to learn the material and reflected what was on the tests.
The assignment was designed to help students understanding the use of the formula and the concept. It would've been more helpful if how those formulas and concepts can be applied in the real world.

narratives.question_text: If tests were given, how fairly did they measure knowledge gained?
comments: The tests can be a bit intimidating. Especially because even though you theoretically have infinite time to finish them, the rest of our schedules and production assignments make that not necessarily true.
The tests are like going through a wringer but definitely require you to understand the material thoroughly.
The exams usually did not contain material that was not taught in class, and stayed on-topic.

Wish if it was more generous in grading about labeling...? Or a courtesy applied for the first test at least then warned in class when the test gets returned? It was a little bit harsh to lose 15 or more points on missing labeling R1 and R2 on the first test.

narratives.question_text: How useful was this course in preparing you for production work?
comments: Now I am starting to understand how scary some of the things I have built in the past really were.

It's a little weird when you get to your assignment and have to solve a structures problem you haven't gotten to in class yet, but at least you know the terminology right off the bat to help you with conversations with other students to help you through the productions problem.
I didnt get to use the knowledge in my prod assignment yet but I am sure I will get to use it at some point

Nobody needs to get injured or killed because a techinal director didn't take the time to run the structures of a beam or column. I can see that budgeting and structual design go hand in hand, which is crucial knowledge for a technical director or ATD in the beginning stages of production work.
Not every production requires structural analysis, but when they do I feel more than prepared to use the material covered so far in real-world applications.
I have not had to run structures on a production assignment yet.

I needed to seek the help of upper class-men to "run the structures" on some pieces that I tech-designed because I had not yet learned some formulas. But we can't know everything about anything on day one.
I haven't designed columns or needed to run structure for my production assignment yet but I would know where to look for and what to use as the reference when I need to in the future.

narratives.question_text: How would you evaluate the instructor's knowledge of the material?
comments: Well, he literally wrote the book on it. Also, he does an excellent job of making the individual topics clear as we move through them from one to another.
I hope whoever teaches this course in the future has the same command of the material. I count myself lucky.
Ben literally wrote the book. What else is there to say?
He wrote the book!
No question. He wrote the book
I don't think I even need to say much on this question. He knows what he's doing.

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments on such topics as: what worked best about the course, suggested improvements, class materials, etc.
comments: this was my hardest course, but the most rewarding
Start introducing how all of these things relate to real life earlier in the class. Like the examples when you ask what kind of theatrical scenario an example is conveying.
If one semester was taught in a year, it would be a lot less intimidating. I know the practicality of that is useless.

I know you will continue teaching after this year, but you will be missed so much when you leave the chair position. I really appreciate your share of knowledge and care for us as more like the father figure than just the head of the department.
